ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This helped me learn more about public health struggles and advancements in the Arab world.
A perspective on health in conflict settings, thinking about building better health systems, current and future  public health challenges, hearing from leading professionals

Professor Nuwayhid's course is a great survey of public health around the Arab World. He brings expert guest speakers to each class that are very knowledgable on the subjects at hand and the class is very informative and engaging.
Much knowledge about public health, and especially how it operates in the region of MENA.

This course was incredibly eye opening. It taught me multitudes on public health in the Arab world, from the inner workings of health systems to the intersections of politics and human rights to environmental threats and so much more. It was very much needed, as the subject is already so vague and requires many more academics to enrich it; but it was rewarding in that the big field names were the same individuals who spoke with us during our sessions. Super super insightful.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strength was the variety of guest speakers that taught lectures, but was also a weakness because cohesion could be improved.

Strength: interesting and diverse class readings which push you to think creatively about solutions to challenges, great discussion format where you can also learn from the perspective of your peers, interesting stimulated debate to be in the shoes of various actors

Professor Nuwayhid and his guests are the highlights. The class time was just too long and late in the day perhaps in the future it could be split into two class periods per week and be earlier in the day.
Amazing guest lecturers. Dr. Iman is the most amazing professor! The course structure was not the best. There was a significant delay in the feedback.

I thought it was done wonderfully. My highest regards to this course. Maybe the writing assignments could have been a bit more clearly articulated in terms of what was required, but still, I felt like it was all very straightforward and we knew what we were going to be doing at almost every session.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I absolutely loved this class and felt for the first time in a long time that the professor genuinely wanted me to just learn
I would recommend this course to anyone from the region or interested in public health.
Yes if you are interested in the subject at hand (especially the Arab World).
Definitely, it is an amazing course and the instructor was super helpful and considerate.

Absolutely!! Its a field so rarely spoken about when discussing public health or even the Arab world as a whole, and most definitely needs more interested people. If you are interested in public health, the Arab World, human rights/education, accessibility, business/management, anything at all, I feel like theres something for you In this class. Always so engaging and so interesting. Dr. Nuwayhid is a gem of a professor, and Yale would be lucky to have him teach this course again.
